awd_titl_txt: IRES: US-China International Student Research Experiences in Plant Genomics
awd_abstract_narration:
This International Research Experiences for Students (IRES) program provides a unique opportunity for collaborative research in plant genome and agricultural biotechnology for a  diverse group of US graduate and undergraduate students. The students will investigate gene function in plants exposed to five major abiotic stressors (drought, salinity, heavy metal lead, low and high temperature). In each of the three award years, five students will be selected from East Carolina University (ECU) and nearby historically black institutes, including local community colleges, in North Carolina. These students will be trained at the ECU PI's laboratories and then travel to China to conduct field and laboratory research at the Henan Institute of Sciences and Technology (HIST) for six weeks.

This IRES project will  impact a broad scientific community  within the US and internationally. The diverse group of students, from 2- and 4- year undergraduate and graduate programs, will receive international mentoring and research-based education. Recruitment from historically black universities and local community colleges in North Carolina with large disadvantaged populations will ensure a diverse student group. Through the proposed student research program in China mentored by Chinese scientists, this IRES project will provide students with unique opportunities to become globally-engaged scientists and to build their international scientific networks.
org_div_long_name: Office of International Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
A total of 23 undergraduate and graduate students (all US citizens; 8 students more than that we proposed in the application) were accepted into this NSF IRES program to perform the advanced research under the direct mentorship of the scientists from our foreign partners. These students were selected from East Carolina University (ECU) and nearby historically black institutes (HBCU, including Elizabeth City State University and Fayetteville State University) and local community colleges (such as Pitt Community College and Lenoir Community College) in North Carolina. These students also came from a diversity of groups, including many minorities such as native Americans and black students.  Through the proposed student research program in China mentored by Chinese scientists, this IRES project provided students with unique opportunities to become globally-engaged scientists and to build their international scientific networks. After attending this program, many community students were transferred to 4-year colleges, and many undergraduate students were entered graduate school for further study in the field of STEM.

For each summer, the students performed research in the field of plant genomics and agricultural biotechnology for 6 to 10 weeks (the proposed program was 6 weeks, we were able to host longer time due to the financial contribution from our host foreign universities). They have studied the impact of different environmental stresses on plant growth and development as well as the regulatory mechanism using both traditional approaches and the advanced genomic approaches, including deep sequencing and CRISPR genome editing. Their results found that all tested environmental stresses (such as nitrogen and potassium deficiency, drought and salinity, extreme temperatures, and heavy metal stress as well as nematode infection) significantly affected plant growth and development, including root development and photosynthesis and further affected plant yield and quality. One of potential mechanism is that these abiotic and biotic stresses induced the aberrant expression of certain small regulatory RNA (such as miRNAs) and protein-coding gene that are involved in different biological and biochemical progress. Targeting these genes using the advanced biotechnical approach such as CRISPR genome editing may enhance plant growth and yield under different stress conditions that become more serious recently because of climate changes. Their research results also found that certain new materials, such as nanoparticles and methionine can be used to promote plant growth and development and contribute to the global food security.

With this IRES program support, 30 publications were published in high impact international journals, and numerous presentations were presented in both local and national conferences.
